etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in State Hospitals Bulletin. From bio- + sociology, probably originally after French bio-sociologie

definitions: The study of how interacting social and biological factors influence human behaviour; specifically a branch of study which uses knowledge or methods from the life sciences to analyse and interpret social behaviour.

notes.text: In later use, considered distinct from sociobiology which seeks to explain the ultimate causes of human and animal behaviour, especially using evolutionary theory.
